reviews.review_text: Not as good as "The discreet hero". This novel is too long for what it portrays, describes, conveys. It should have been edited before publishing. The plots of the various stories are often far-fetched. The best story in the book is, of course, the main character's, the author himself, with his pals and friends, their life, in their environment, at the time of his youth in Lima.

I wanted to read a book based in Peru. I liked learning about modern Peruvian life. I liked the first person story telling of the main character. But the interweaving of other tales were not that interesting. The main love story was a bit blah, and the ending too. I wouldn't really recommend it.

This author was recommended to me by a friend I had recently met. I am not sure what this friend likes about this writing. I found the many story lines punishing to get through. The flip between "reality" of daily living and the fantasy of the soap opera writer was confusing. If the author won major awards for this kind of prose it must be because it is unlike anything else written. My feelings for the characters would just become close when the character disappears. I felt sorry for the protagonist and for the author who must live such a messy life. The abrupt ending was typical of the book. A young man's selfish story of making do in life without contributing to anyone's welfare. Very selfish.

Enjoyable and beautifully written. I particularly enjoyed the main story running through the book. By the end I was struggling with reading yet another of the radio serial stories interspersed throughout the book and started to skim read them - they were fabulously written, inventive and showed a slice of South American life in weird and wonderful ways but maybe there were one or two too many.
One of his best; I laughed and laughed and wanted to say thank you to the author.
It is an entertaining read with a lot of humor. Not a great book. We read it for our men's book group.
Much of the humor gets lost in translation.

My interest waned towards the end. It seemed like Vargas Llosa was enjoying himself as he went along without too much regard for holding on to the reader's attention. Brilliant flashes, but seemed less "serious" than many of his books, by which I don't mean it was humorous (which of course it was).

summary:
Mario Vargas Llosa's brilliant, multilayered novel is set in the Lima, Peru, of the author's youth, where a young student named Marito is toiling away in the news department of a local radio station. His young life is disrupted by two arrivals.

The first is his aunt Julia, recently divorced and thirteen years older, with whom he begins a secret affair. The second is a manic radio scriptwriter named Pedro Camacho, whose racy, vituperative soap operas are holding the city's listeners in thrall. Pedro chooses young Marito to be his confidant as he slowly goes insane.

Interweaving the story of Marito's life with the ever-more-fevered tales of Pedro Camacho, Vargas Llosa's novel is hilarious, mischievous, and masterful, a classic named one of the best books of the year by the New York Times Book Review.
